Message.Title: THANKS BEST! For forcing Jen to finally pay us a Dividend!
Message.Msg: THANKS BEST! For forcing Jen to finally pay us a Dividend! NINETEEN (19) long dividend-less years, boys. Since 1993. When Jen and two other co-founders started nvidia. Jen has been hoarding the shareholder's cash. Yes, just hoarding it, boys. And not paying any Dividend to his hapless shareholders. Goose egg, For 19 long years, as follows: . 1993 __ Shareholders paid their money in, hoping for some nice Dividends back. 1994 __ No cash dividend 1995 __ No cash dividend 1996 __ No cash dicivend 1997 __ No cash dividend 1998 __ No cash dividend 1999 __ No cash dividend 2000 __ No cash dividend 2001 __ Quite an Odyssey -- No cash dividend 2002 __ No cash dividend 2003 __ No cash dividend 2004 __ No cash dividend 2005 __ No cash dividend 2006 __ No cash dividend 2007 __ No cash dividend 2008 __ No cash dividend 2009 __ No cash dividend 2010 __ No cash dividend 2011 __ No cash dividend 2012 __ Jen surrenders just nine (9) days after Best calls him out -- and declares a Dividend. Now, I'm not sure what happened to the other two co-founders of nvidia, -- the two guys that didn't work at Denny's -- but malnutrition is highly likely. And then Best entered the ring. Yes, Boom-Boom Best. The fearless Righter-of-Wrongs and Defender of the Alpha-less. And on October 27th 2012, Best went mano-a-mano with Jen right here. On this very global forum. Disclosing the little know fact that Everybody except Jen paid a dividend. Yes, a Cash Dividend, boys. Paid in Cash to the Owners of the Company, don't u know. And Best, along with his usual entourage of Bestville denizens, called Jen out. And called him out Badly. Yes boys, a showdown at the Not Okay Corral. And you know what? Jen quickly surrendered under the insufferable pressure of Best's postings. (Which by the way, can be read and re-read at your leisure -- just look for the highly popular posting entitled, "Jeepers Best, Everybody else pays a dividend.") And just nine (9) business days later, Jen capitulated to Best's intellectually honest demands -- and announced the First Ever Cash Dividend in the History of nvidia. So don't believe it, boys. Oh no no no. When folks say that postings on Our fine board don't matter. They DO matter -- A LOT -- and can change the course of a cheap company's history. If you don't believe it, just ask current CEO Jen. AND THANKS AGAIN BEST! For forcing Jen to finally pay us a Dividend! You're truly, well, The Best.

Message.Title: What does Jen's new dividend means to a typical holder of 100 nvidia shares?.
Message.Msg: So Jen declares a $00.075 per share dividend, right? What's it mean to a typical holder of 100 nvda shares? Hummm? Let's examine the issue, shall we? 100 shares x $00.075 per share dividend = $7.50 Still with me, boys? Okay then. So what can we do with that? Well, let's contemplate that over lunch, shall we? $2.90 __ One (1) Big Mac $1.50 __ One (1) Large McFries $1.50 __ One (1) Medium Strawberry McShake $1.20 __ One (1) Apple McPie $0.74 __ Applicable taxes (yours may vary) _____ $7.84 __ Total Why, Best. Jen's dividend of $7.50 doesn't even buy the typical nvidia shareholder lunch! For one (1) day. My my my. THIS is, well, McDisappointing. The headline sounds so Good, right boys? "NVIDIA Corporation declares it's First Ever Cash Dividend." But the Reality is, well, quite different.

Message.Title: New NVIDIA Driver ‘Doubles Performance’ on Linux
Message.Msg: "The latest NVidia GeForce driver, released yesterday, gives Linux users ‘double the performance’ and ‘dramatically reduces game loading times’, according to the company’s press release. Having been in development for almost a year, the GeForce R310 driver has been designed to ‘showcase the enormous potential of the world’s biggest open-source operating system’. NVIDIA collaborated with Valve and other games developers in designing the driver, having been ‘thoroughly tested’ with the Steam for Linux beta. “With this release, NVIDIA has managed to increase the overall gaming performance under Linux,” Valve’s head of marketing is quoted as saying. “NVIDIA took an unquestioned leadership position developing R310 drivers with us and other studios to provide an absolutely unequalled solution for Linux gamers.”

Message.Title: Dividend changed the game
Message.Msg: Jen is right to not only issue a dividend but retain the stock buyback. I also agree that once they can get 4G LTE products working on their chips this company will be a monster going forward. The chip market is not running away from them and China/ foreign markets are really doing well for NVDA products. The naysayers will keep talking but the company is making more right moves and the cash is building up slowly but building. In essence, I see NVDA at $20-25 during either 3rd or 4th qtr 2013. Mutual funds will be more open to hold NVDA now that they offer a dividend.

Message.Title: ASUS Undercuts Microsoft Surface With $549 VivoTab RT
Message.Msg: Like the move. This kind of competition is health and drivel overall Windows RT tablet expansion. =================== While I can’t personally vouch for the overall quality of the VivoTab RT, the manufacturer has a strong track record with its Android Transformer line, and this particular slate boasts an incredible 600nit compared to the 400nit luminosity of the Surface. The VivoTab further distinguishes itself with its 8MP rear camera (as opposed to the primary 5MP camera on the Surface) and an additional 7 hours of rated battery life via its docking station. The docking station also includes a keyboard, trackpad and MicroSD card slot. ASUS is offering the optional dock for free through December 31st, 2012. If price is a concern and you’re in the market for a post-PC hybrid tablet running Windows RT, the VivoTab may be a tempting proposition. It also matches the Surface’s 2GB of RAM and 32GB of internal storage, and is powered by NVIDIA’s Tegra 3 chip. If patience is your game, stick around for hands-on impressions of the VivoTab RT and a full review of Microsoft’s Surface. The ASUS VivoTab RT is currently available for $549 at Amazon and NewEgg.

Message.Title: Fiscal Cliff Fears Creating Potential for Bargain Buys (NVDA
Message.Msg: In earnings news, chip maker NVIDIA (NVDA) said its fiscal third-quarter profit rose to $209 million, or 33 cents per share, from $178 million, or 29 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 13% to $1.2 billion. Analysts had expected a profit of 30 cents per share on revenue of $1.19 billion. NVIDIA forecast fourth-quarter revenue of $1.02-$1.18 billion, just below the $1.2 billion consensus. Shares of NVIDIA fell -3.9%.

Topic.Title: What does Jen's new dividend means to a typical holder of 100 nvidia shares?.

Message.Msg: "You forgot that on that $7.50 dividend, you first have to pay applicable income taxes - currently 15%, but probably going up to 25% with the Democrats running everything," Actually, Jen's dividend gets taxed Three times. Yes, THREE times, boys. First, nvidia pays taxes on their net income Before distributing the dividend. Then the hapless nvidia shareholder pays tax on their dividend received. And then pays sales tax Again on whatever they buy with it -- in this case almost lunch at Mcdonald's. Assuming that the hapless nvda shareholder spends the dividend. Which is probably a safe assumption. Since that $7.50 is juuuust a little small to be forming a multi-generational trust fund.

Topic.Title: Like a flag at half-staff, lowered guidance is a sad thing.

Message.Msg: "Like a flag at half-staff, lowered guidance is a sad thing. Right boys? It sure is. For the three months just ended, nvidia had revenue of $1.204 billion. Yet Jen confessed last night that guidance for the Next three months could be as low as $1.025 billion. As much as (-$179,000,000.00) Lower than the quarter just ended. And Much Lower than the average analysts' expectations of $1.206 billion, according to Thompson Reuters I/B/E/S. Did I mention? Like a flag at half-staff, lowered guidance is a sad thing." So Master? First, I must say that's a fine, very well written explaination of why nvda stock came Crashing down today. Following Jen's significantly lowered guidance. Very well written. But secondly, I have a question. We all know that The Market is a forward-looking, cash discounting machine. Like an Italian in a little sports car. Who snaps-off the rear view mirror 'cause, "what's behind him don'ta matter". This we all understand. But how long does it take, Master? The process of The Market reducing expectations and the nvda stock price accordingly -- to reflect the new sucky future and guidance. A couple months? Okay. Thanks Master. You're the Best.
